title: Comecon: Energy supply problem?
Future uranium supply and demand
A pulsed power supply for injection bump magnets
Optimal Scheduling of Water Supply Projects
items.abstract: <jats:p>Some capacity expansion problems encountered in water resources development are studied. Models yielding least-cost shedules (i.e. optimal selection and sequencing of potential projects) in order to meet a stipulated increase in water demand are first discussed. However, recognizing uncertainties in the future demand, these ought to be taken into account. In order to do this, a new general dynamic programming algorithm has been developed. Depending on how detailed we are able to state the preferences against shortage, chance-constraints or penalty functions are included in the optimization. The use of the algorithm, as an aid in the current planning, is illustrated by solving an example under deterministic as well as stochastic assumptions about the future demand.</jats:p>

Viruses in Water Supply
items.abstract: <jats:p>In comparison with information concerning bacterial contamination of water supplies, much less is known about viruses in water because few water systems determine the presence of viral pollutants in their supplies, although various techniques exist for delineating the presence of viruses. A summary of the advantages and disadvantages of the various techniques is given along with the recommendations of APHA concerning detection and control of waterborne viruses.</jats:p>

title: Development of the Equine Hypophysis Cerebri, with a Reference to Its Blood Supply
items.abstract: <jats:sec><jats:title>Summary</jats:title><jats:p>The development of the equine hypophysis and its blood supply was investigated in embryos and fetuses from ca. the 22nd to 270th day of gestation. The developing equine primary capillary plexus was supplied by the right and left rostral (ventral and dorsal) infundibular arteries, which were constant branches of the right and left internal carotid arteries, or their terminal rami, respectively. The early cellular proliferation and differentiation of Rathke's pouch were accompanied by penetration of vessels from the primary capillary plexus into the developing pars tuberalis. These vessels represented the primitive portal vessels. The development of the ventral group of portal vessels preceded that of the dorsal group of portal vessels. In the fetuses at the terminal half of gestation, the primary capillary plexus, with its superficial and deep components of the ventral and dorsal walls of the median eminence, and the ventral and dorsal groups of portal vessels, resembled that of the postnatal animals. The caudal infundibular artery (single or paired) appeared as a branch of the arteria intercarotica caudalis relatively late in the development and supplied the neural lobe. The portal vessels were the sole blood supply to the developing equine pars distalis; there was no evidence of a direct arterial supply to the pars distalis at any time during embryonic and fetal development. The early appearance and differentiation of the equine portal system suggested the onset of its function in the fetal life.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Zusammenfassung</jats:title><jats:p>Entwicklung der Hypophyse des Pferdes unter Berücksichtigung ihrer Gefäßversorgung</jats:p><jats:p>Die Entwicklung der Pferde‐Hypophyse und ihrer Gefäßversorgung wurde an Embryonen und Feten etwa vom 22.‐270. Trächtigkeitstag unter‐sucht. Der primäre Kapillarplexus wurde von der rechten und linken (ventra‐len und dorsalen) Infundibulararterie versorgt, die konstante Zweige der Aa. carotides intt. respektive und deren Endästen waren. Die frühe Zellproliferation samt Differenzierung der Rathkeschen Tasche waren von Gefäßeinspros‐sungen des primären Kapillarplexus in die sich entwickelnde Pars tuberalis begleitet. Diese Gefäße stellten die primitiven Portalgefäße dar. Dabei entwickelte sich die ventrale Gruppe der Portalgefäße früher als die dorsale. Etwa im neunten Trächtigkeitsmonat ähnelten die Kapillarplexus mit ihren oberflächlichen und tiefen Anteilen für die Ventral‐ und Dorsalwand der Eminentia mediana sowie audi die ventrale und dorsale Gruppe der Portal‐gefässe dem postnatalen Zustand. Die kaudale Infundibulararterie (unpaar oder paarig) erschien als Ast der A. intercarotica caud. relativ spät und versorgte den Lobus neuralis. Die Portalgefäße allein versorgten die Pars distalis; es bestanden keinerlei Anzeichen für deren direkte arterielle Versorgung bei Embryonen und Feten. Dieses frühe Auftreten und Ausbilden des Portalgefäß‐systems legen seinen Funktionsbeginn während des Fetallebens nahe.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Résumé</jats:title><jats:p>Développement de ľhypophyse de Cheval et de sa vascularisation</jats:p><jats:p>Le développement de ľhypophyse du Cheval et sa vascularisation ont étéétudiés sur des embryons et des foetus dont ľâage allait de 22 à 270 jours de gestation. Le plexus capillaire initial est fourni par les artéres infundibulaires rostrales (ventrale et dorsale) droites et gaudies, lesquelles se sont montrees des branches constantes des artères carotides internes, respectivement droite et gauche, ou de leurs rameaux terminaux. Les premières poussées cellulaires et la différenciation de la poche de Rathke sont accompagnées par la pénétration de branches du plexus capillaire primitif dans ľébauche de la pars tuberalis. Ces vaisseaux représentent le système porte primitif. Le développement du groupe ventral des vaisseaux portes précède celui du groupe dorsal. Dans les foetus de la deuxième moitié de la gestation, le plexus capillaire primitif, avec ses parties superficielles et profondes dans les parois dorsale et ventrale de ľéminence médiane, et les groupes ventral el dorsal de vaisseaux portes ressemblent à ceux du nouveau‐né. Ľartère infundibulaire caudale (simple ou double) apparaît comme une branche de ľartère intercarotique caudale relativement tard dans le développement et irrigue le lobe nerveux. Les vaisseaux portes ont constitué, chez les Equidés la seule source ďirrigation de la pars distalis en cours de développement; on n'a pu mettre en évidence ďémission arteriélle directe à destination de la pars distalis, à aucun moment du développement embryonnaire ou foetal. Ľapparition et la différenciation précoces du système porte hypophysaire du Cheval laissent supposer que sa fonction débute dans la période foetale.</jats:p></jats:sec><jats:sec><jats:title>Resumen</jats:title><jats:p>Desarrollo de la hipófisis del caballo considerando su vascularización</jats:p><jats:p>En embriones y fetos del caballo aproximadamente entre 22 y 270 días de la gestación, se estudió el desarrollo de la hipófisis y de su vascularización. El plexo capilar primordial se originó de las arterias infundibulares derecha e izquierda (ventral y dorsal), que eran ramas constantes de las art. Carótidas internas o de sus ramas terminales respectivamente. Las proliferaciones tempranas y la diferenciación de las células de la bolsa de Rathke se vieron acompañadas de la penetración de brotes vasculares en la pars tuberalis a partir del plexo capilar primario. Estos vasos correspondieron a los vasos portales primitivos, desarrollándose las ramas portales ventrales antes de las dorsales. Hacia el final de la primera mitad de la gestación, los plexos capilares con sus porciones superficiales y profundas para las paredes ventral y dorsal de la eminencia mediana y las ramas portales ventrales y dorsales, tenían mucha semejanza con su situación postnatal. La arteria infundibular caudal (par o impar) se presentó como una rama de la A. intercarótica caudal en épocas bastante tardías, irrigando el Lobus neuralis. Sólo los vasos portales irrigaron la Pars distalis; en los embriones y fetos no existieron senales para la irrigación directa de la misma. Tal aparición y desarrollo tempranos del sistema portal permiten suponer el inicio de su funcionamiento ya durante la vida fetal.</jats:p></jats:sec>

Capillary supply of skeletal muscle fibers in untrained and endurance-trained men
container-title: American Journal of Physiology-Heart and Circulatory Physiology
items.abstract: <jats:p> Muscle fiber diameters and numbers of capillaries per fiber, per square millimeter, and around each fiber were determined in needle biopsies from the lateral part of the quadriceps muscle of 23 young men. Twelve subjects were untrained (UT) and eleven were endurance-trained (ET) athletes. Average values for maximal oxygen uptake were 51.3 (UT) and 72.0 ml/kg-min (ET). Mean fiber diameters were not significantly different in the two groups (48.8 and 49.1 micron). The capillaries per fiber ratios were 1.77+/-0.10 and 2.49+/-0.08 (mean+/-SE) in the UT and ET groups, respectively. The numbers of capillaries around each fiber were 4.43+/-0.19 (UT) and 5.87+/-0.18 (ET). The numbers of capillaries per mm2 were 585+/-40 (UT) and 821+/-28 (ET). Fiber diameters were 28% smaller in ultrathin than in fresh-frozen sections from the same biopsies. After correction for this difference, the numbers of capillaries per mm2 were 305 and 425 in the UT and ET, respectively. The capillaries per fiber ratio increased with increasing fiber diameter, but not sufficiently to maintain the number of capillaries per mm2. Fibers containing many mitochondria are surrounded by more capillaries than fibers with few mitochondria. </jats:p>

title: PREDICTING INSTANTANEOUS PEAK DEMAND IN RURAL DOMESTIC WATER SUPPLY SYSTEMS<sup>1</sup>
container-title: JAWRA Journal of the American Water Resources Association
items.abstract: <jats:p><jats:bold>ABSTRACT: </jats:bold> Many rural areas of the United States still have no public domestic water systems. Typical land use patterns in these areas may require 1/2 mile or more of pipe per farm connection. Public systems serving these areas are economically feasible only if realistic short‐term peak demand standards are available for their design. The lack of reliable data upon which to establish such criteria has resulted in a large variation in criteria among state and federal agencies involved in financing and in approving construction of these systems. During the summer of 1975 three distribution laterals of a rural system in Utah were master metered and instantaneous peak flows were recorded for 4 months. The metered lines served 4, 12, and 22 farm houses each. The frequency distribution of peak flows has been analyzed and compared with that developed during similar research in Mississippi and with the existing design standards of the Farmers Home Administration and the State of Utah.</jats:p>
